questions.question: ‘I can’t swim.’ ‘………………….. can I.’
questions.description: After a negative idea, we can add another negative idea with neither.

questions.question: Ruth didn’t turn up. Margaret didn’t ……………………………
questions.description: After mentioning a negative idea, we can add another negative idea by using ‘not…either’.

questions.question: James didn’t pass the test. ………………………… did Samuel.
questions.description: We can use neither / nor to mean ‘not … either’ after a negative idea.

questions.question: ‘I don’t like opera.’ ‘…………………………..’
questions.description: ‘Neither do I’ means the same as ‘I don’t either.’

questions.question: Our main need is not food, ………………………. jobs. It is education.
questions.description: Nor can follow not. It is more emphatic than or.

questions.question: James was not at home, and ………………………… was Alice.
questions.description: Neither or nor can be used here

questions.question: He neither smiled ………………………… looked at me.
questions.description: Neither…nor is used to join two negative ideas.

questions.question: She not only sings she ………………………… dances.
questions.description: Also goes in mid position. As well and too usually go at the end of a clause.

questions.question: She is not only rich she is famous ……………………………
questions.description: As well or too is possible here.

questions.question: ‘She is pretty.’ ‘Her sister is …………………………’
questions.description: As well can be used in short answers. Also is not normally used in short answers.

questions.question: It is a small house. …………………………, it needs a lot of repairs.
questions.description: Also can go at the beginning of a clause to refer to the whole clause.
